div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
THE STAY AT MADAGASCAR
FRENCH NEUTRALITY.

div.p: Despite the resentment at the prolonged t. sojourn of the Baltic Fleet at Madagascar, it is unlikely there will be any further outcome of this feeling, which it is believed was based on a misapprehension regarding French neutrality regulations. The latter differ totally from the British, since they place no limit on the stay of a belligerent in French ports, unless accompanied by a prize. It is pointed out that the Japanese may enjoy similar advantages at Saigon.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
THE RUSSIAN RAID.
JAPS SUFFER SEVERELY.

div.p: General Kuropatkin, reporting the cavalry 1 raid, says that the Japanese outflanked a column of the Russian cavalry, which was retiring northward. An engagement ensued | during which the Japanese suffered severely d from the fire of the Russian artillery. The v Russians retired in good order, losing 5 officers and 50 mien killed and wounded. (Reuter.)
It is stated here that Mistchenko's cavalry regained the Russian lines with all their wounded.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR GARRISON.
OFFICERS EMBARK FOR EUROPE.

div.p: General Stoessel and 245 officers have sailed for Europe.
(Reuter.)

Mr. Hay has cabled to the American Minister at Peking drawing attention to the Russian note regarding the question of neutrality, and stating that he hopes China will earnestly consider the charges made against her.
(Reuter.)
Japan is constructing a first-class armoured cruiser at Kure.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
RUSSIAN IRON STRIKE.
40,000 MEN GOING OUT.

div.p: The Putiloff strike is due to the dismissal of four unionist men. Three other works are going on strike to-day in sympathy with the ironworkers. The strikers will then number 40,000.
(Reuter.)
The Putiloff ironworks are the largest here. The strikers disclaim any Socialist connections, but the police and military have taken pre cautions.
(Reuter.)
It is reported that the Dalai Lama is leaving Urga for Kiakhta.
(Reuter.)

div.head: BLIZZARD IN ENGLAND,
div.p: THAMES ESTUARY FROZEN
COAST STREWN WITH WRECKS
LONDON, January 17. A blizzard swept over England yesterday. The Thames estuary was frozen for a considerable distance from the shore.
Showers of ice fell in London, where the traffic was disorganised. The coast is strewn with wrecks. Several deaths are reported from cold.

div.head: ATTEMPTED MURDER AND SUICIDE.-
div.p: A Russian living in the Attarin quarter shot his wife in the arm with a revolver and afterwards turned the revolver on himself, blowing his brains out. The woman is lying in hospital. |

div.head: H. M. TRANSPORT
div.p: "Plassy" (Capt. F. H. Seymour) arrived at Port Said yesterday moruing from Bombay with 1,113 troops of all ranks on board. Major Westmoreland, 1st Warwick Regiment, is the officer commanding. The "Plassy' lett for Southampton at 2 p.m.

div.head: CAIRO STREETS. —
div.p: The work of improving Abbas:boulevard, Cairo, has begun. The filling up of the banks of Ismailia Canal is being proceeded with actively. It is stated that the asphalting of Clot Bey-street will be completely finished by the end of the month. I

div.head: PREVENTION OF TUBERCULOSIS. --
div.p: In yesterday's Orders of the Army of Occupation, the attention of the officers commanding units is invited to the desiravility, for sanitary reasons, and particularly for the prévention of tuberculosis, of taking steps to repress the prevalent habit of spitting in barrack rooms, canteens, etc.

div.head: IMPERIAL OTTOMAN BANK. —
div.p: Mr. Giovanni Sugiani, an old and tried ufficial of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, who was lately manager of the Smyrua agency, has been sent to the Cairo agency, pending the appointment of a manager. M. Robin, who has been assisting in the management, resumes his former duties as inspector.

div.head: Suez CANAL.
div.p: -- 35 vessels passed through the Canal on the 13th and 14th inst., the receipts for the two days being frs. 879,577.52. 27 of the ships were British, 3 German, 1 Austrian, 2 French, 2 Norwegian. The total receipts from 1st to 14th inst. were frs. 5,352,186.25.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB. -
div.p: As already announced, the first of a series of smoking concerts will take place in Monferrato's Hall on Saturday next at 9 p.m. promptly. During the interval the prizes won by members will be presented. An excellent programme has been arranged. Members entitled to prizes are asked to communicate with the hon. secretary.

div.head: EXHIBITION OF WATER-COLOURS.—
div.p: On Thursday next an exhibition of water-colour draw ings will be held at the Cercle Artistique and will remain open for ten days. M. Barbier, the artist, is a member of the Société des Artistes Français, 'lauréat of the Salon de Paris in 1904, and is painter to H. R. H. the Prince of Bulgaria.

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.—
div.p: The journal of the Chamber for January contains the Financial Adviser's Note on the Budget, the translation of Lord Cromer's reply to the Chamber of Shipping re the port of Alexandria, an article on the Law Courts of Egypt, I a review of the stock and share market, etc.

div.head: MAN SHOT BY TOURISTS.—
div.p: The Moudir of Ghizeh, in a report which he has sent to the Ministry of the Interior, states that two American tourists, who were indulging in some sport on their way down the river on a steamer, accidentally shot an inhabitant of Half, who succumbed to his injuries. The | vessel was stopped and the sportsmen were arrested.

div.head: SERATO RECITAL.-
div.p: Signor Serato gave another very successful recital on Monday afternoon at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, which was very well attended. His rendering of Beethoven's concerto for the violin, p. 0.61, was received with tumultuous applause. Signor Serato will give a recital at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, on Friday next, 20th inst., at 9 p.m.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE.—
div.p: Last night a new and highly successful item was added to the excellent programme now in force at Alexandria's popular theatre of varieties. This was the duettists Raphael and Colombel, who were excellent and aroused great enthusiasm among the audience by their extremely clever singing and mimicry. The rest of the programme is as | bright as ever and the comic ballet, "La Belle du Moulin," deserves a visit for itself alone.

div.head: ENGLISH FURNITURE IN EGYPT. –
div.p: Mr. T. Oliver, the representative of Messrs. Maple 1 & Co., Las arrived in Egypt, where he will stay for some weeks, as the great Tottenham Court-road furnishing firm has many orders to execute here both on behalf of Government Administrations and Departments as well as for hotels and private individuals. The taste for good English-made furniture is growing in Egypt, and this well-known house makes a speciality of furniture suitable for hot climates. Mr. Oliver will be at Shepheard's Hotel until the 10th proxo., after which date he will be at Alexandria for a visit of three weeks' duration. As showing the ramifications of the business we may mention that Messrs. Maple are now completing the furnishing of a new palace at Bangkok for the King of Siam, as well as the furnishing of large public buildings for the Argentine Republic at Buenos Ayres.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will visit the Awalad Ema Mosque for prayers on Friday.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has been graciously pleased to bestow the following grades and decorations on the undermentioned officials in the Egyptian Government service on the occasion of their retirement:

MINISTRY OF THE INTERIOR. Sanieh : Elias Kheir Bey, late of the Contentieux Department, Ministry of the Interior; Sid Ahmed Chalach Bey, Mamour of the Beni Souef district. | Salissah : El-Sayed Sadek Effendi, late Mamour of the Assouan district ; Mohamed | Tewfik Effendi, late Mamour of the Fareskour district.
Osmanieh, Officer (4th class) : M. Padoue de Peretti, late of the Contentieux Department.
L WAR OFFICE. Salissah : - Ishak Guirguis Effendi, on his transfer to the Sudan.

p.hi: DAIRA SANIEH. Moutamaiz: Mohamed El-Nemani Bey, late inspector of Rodah.

div.p: Sanieh : Farag Guirguis Bey, late of the Daira Sanieh, Alexandria.

p.hi: Medjidieh, Commander (3rd class): Mahmoud El Chafii Bey, late inspector of Abou Korkas.

div.p: RAILWAY ADMINISTRATION. Salissah : Aly Effendi Aly. Rabea : Suleiman Omar Effendi.

div.head: THE HOLY CARPET.
div.p: This afternoon two detachments of the 16th Battalion Egyptian Army, headed by the band, will reach Gamalieh at 3.30 p.m. to escort the Holy Carpet to the Mastabat el Mahmal in Mohamed Aly-square.

On Thursday morning the 16th Battalion, Cavalry, and Artillery will arrive at Mohamed Aly-square at 9.30 a.m. to pay the usual honors to H.H. the Khedive and to escort the Mahmal to Abbassieh. A salvo of 21 guns will be fired on the arrival and the departure | of his Highness.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Neva," of the Westcott and Laurance Line, left Malta yesterday and is due here on Saturday afternoon with a general cargo from London.
The Khedivial Mail S.S. "El Kahira" will leave Alexandria on Saturday for Jaffa, Caiffa, Beyrout, Tripoli, Mersina, Alexandretta, Lar naca, Limassol and Port Said.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, LUXOR
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its position on Nile bank. Under German Management. Moderate Charges. Patronised by officers of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily. Propietors: Moroni & Manusardi

ings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose e monthly publication reviews our commercey The annual subscription is £1 and all British s traders should become members. Our London

div.head: KHARTOUM FULL OF
div.p: TOURISTS.
SOCIAL DOINGS.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)

Khartoum, January 12. Whether it is still due to the novelty of the thing, or to the ideal weather, Khartoum is gradually filling up with tourists. The Grand Hotel already contains about 50 guests, and thanks to the excellent string band of the Rifle Brigade, Saturday evenings prove an attraction for dinner parties.

I noticed last Saturday Major Nicol, R.B., with a party of 12, the Earl of Londesborough and Lord Cholmondeley with 12 friends, Captain Drake with two, and Capt. Mears with two. Mr. Davidson, manager of the Bank of Egypt here, entertained a party of 6, Mr. Struvé, inspector, a party of 5, Capt. Parsons & party of four, Major Persse & party of two, Bimb. Elderton a party of four, and Dr. Beam a party of two.
The large dining-hall and the table were beautifully decorated, and dancing was indulged in up to a late hour.

For Saturday next tables have been secured) by Mr. and Mrs. Leigh Hunt for a party of 20, including Lord and Lady Southwell, Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pasha, and others; Mr. Joseph Walton, M.P., for 5 ; Bimb. Rome and Meyricke for 12 ; Bimb. Channer for 6, and a great many more.

It appears that several tourists intend to stay over the visit of the Duke of Connaught and witness the festivities in prospect. It is expected that his Royal Highness will open the annual Agricultural Show on the 3rd February, while there will, of course, be a review of the troops, illuminations, and other functions.

div.head: UPPER NILE NOTES.
div.p: Khartoum, January 9. * During the past two weeks, it seems, a great deal of excitement has prevailed among the officials and employés of both the Sennar and Ghezireh Moudiriehs, on learning that Ghezireh headquarters would be transferred to Wad Medani, which is the most important and populous town of the Sennar Moudirieh. This step, I believe, has been induced by the fact that Ghezireh Moudirich is not large enough and has, moreover, been of late reduced, two important markazes having been taken and added to the new moudirieh, with its seat at Duem, and now called White Nile Province.
Sennar Moudirieh headquarters will be transferred to Singa, which town has acquired great importance since the recent outrage which took place there.

Two new markazes, it is said, will be created on the Abyssinian boundary. The date whers these changes will be carried into effect has not yet been fixed, but it is presumed that they will take place before next October.
Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pasha went to Wad Medani last week and inspected the different tribes of the Moudīrieh, afterwards returning here.
Ghezireh Moudírieh is to be called Blue Nile Province, to correspond with the new moudirieh, White Nile Province.

div.head: LAND VALUES IN EGYPT.
div.p: In concluding a notice of Mr. Lang Anders son's article on "Land Values in Egypt," the "Morning Post" remarks : "On the whole Mr. Lang Anderson makes out a very good case for a high value of land, but it must not be 83sumed that he justifies the present high values of Egyptian securities. Incidentally, when explaining that the return on Egyptian stocks and shares is not attractive enough to draw capital from those who would otherwise invest it in land, he remarks that in the case of most of the companies with a future that future has already been discounted at a price disproportionate to the prospects."

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: LA GIOCONDA. Monday's performance was "frankly uninspiring : the orchestra was as good as it always is and the chorus better than usual, | but the performance of Ponchielli's melodrama, which requires the very best singing and acting to be bearable, in spite of the good points in the second act and the graceful melodic de signs of the "Dance of the Hours," was mediocre. And mediocrity spells boredom ih
the case of "La Gioconda." Sig. Nani threw a | certain amount of vigour into his singing : the
fine song-in our opinion the best in the | piece Pescator affonda l'esca' was well given

and duly encored, and owing to the fact that he acted with power even the dullest scenes in which he appeared were invested with some interest. Artistically the rest were on a different level : Signa. Pinto could not always control a vigorous voice and constantly overcharged it with emotion, with lamentable re. sults. Sig. Bravi was fair, not in the least remarkable, and in consequence & failure, for to make "La Gioconda" interesting throughout the singing and acting must be first-class. The rest were fair and uninspired, and the performance fulfilled our worst fears, a moderate performance of a moderate and melodramatic opera being worse by many degrees than a real perversion of, say, "Lohengrin," assuming that the orchestra plays both equally well. You can always look to the orchestra tor comfort in the latter case, in the former it intensifies your glooma.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves for the responsible opinions expressed
by our oortospondents, but we wish in spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion. .

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN HOSPITAL.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, -The latter of the chairman of the above institution, which appeared in your columns of the 16th inst., contains several interesting particulars, but it does not furnish quite all the information désired. I would, therefore, ask you, Sir, to grant me space to repeat my unanswered question, and to add a few mote which arise out of his reply :

(a). Was it one of the objects of the founders of this hospital to provide accommodation for maternity cases generally, or especially for the wives of soldiers belonging to the Army of Occupation ; and was the fact so stated in the original appeal to the public for contributions ? If such was not the case, when was it publicly intimated that the hospital was to be used for that purpose ?
(6). What is the date of the arrangement between the Army of Occupation and the hospital authorities, and when was the public first informed of that arrangement ?

(c). For what term does that arrangement remain in force ? Does it empower the hospital authorities to put an end to it before the date of its expiry, and, if so, in what circumstances and upon giving what length of notice ?
(d). Does the arrangement assign any limit to the number of maternity cases that the hospital is bound to admit simultaneously?
(@). For what period, under the arrangement, are the hospital authorities required to retain maternity cases, and what is the usual time during which such cases remain in the hospital?
I am, &c.,
CAIRENE. Cairo, January 17.

div.head: THE WAKFS AND INDUSTRIAL DWELLINGS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—Would it not be within the sphere of operations of the Wakfs Administration to invest some of the funds at their disposal in building dwellings for the labouring classes and other employés, on some of the lands under their control outside the city ? No doubt the Tramway Company would agree to establish a special service for workmen night and morning to meet the requirements of the men, if sites were chosen which their cars could serve. · Such a course would be a desirable one for many reasons ; it would supply a very real want from a sanitary point ot view, and should be profitable, useful, and very popular.
I am, etc.,
Geo. B. ALDERSON Bulkeley, January 17.

div.head: THE CHURCH OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: In no province of eastern Christendom is the Church's early history more obscure than in that of Alexandria. Until the middle of the I third century, we have to be content with the meagrest list of names and only occasionally a fuller biographical notice (as in the case of Origen or of Dionysius). And for these scants materials we are indebted solely to Eusebius. The patriarchal chronicle of Severus of Ashmunain, whereof we have the first instalment in "The History of the Patriarchs of the Coptic Church of Alexandria." 1, St. Mark to Theonas (300) (Arabic text edited, translated, and annotated by B. Evetts ; being tome I., fasc. 2, of the Patrologia Orientalis, edited by R. Graffin and F. Nau. Paris. Didot), is, like all similar compilations, dependent, more or less immediately, upon this common source. How many degrees its author is removed from the Greek text has yet to be ascertained. For alI though & Coptic version--and that a very inaccurate one-of the "Ecclesiastical History" has recently been brought to light, we know, from Severus's own words, that he was unable to make use even of this without the further medium of an Arabic translation. From one of the three prefaces which introduce the chronicle, we learn how he laboriously collected his | materials among the monastic libraries of Egypt, and how friends aided him with translations of Coptic as well as of Greek manuscripts. A comparison of the resultant Arabic with the Greek of Eusebius shows, as was to be expected, that successive translations have often taken us a long way from the meaning of the original text. However, it is not as a translator of Eusebius that Severus is of importance : he had access to documents of which not rarely he alone preserves a knowledge, as, for instance, in his account of the patriarch Demetrius; and he drew besides upon sources probably unknown outside Egypt, as in his notices of certain of the Diocletian martyrs, and par
ticularly of Peter 1. But the latter bishop | does not come within the limits of the present I fascicule. It is, indeed, on account of the

latter periods of his chronicle that Severus so well deserves complete publication. From the Arab invasion till the middle of the ninth century the work is rightly called by his name ; after his death, a hundred years | later, the record is carried on by successive continuators down to the thirteenth century. Throughout all that period we are dependent almost exclusively upon it for information has to the state of the Alexandrine Church,
the concerns of which are rarely so much as mentioned by Mohamedan writers.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Earl of Londesborough and Lord George Cholmondeley are expected at the Savoy Hotel to-morrow morning from their trip to Khartoum.
Baron von Bassus, an annual visitor of the Savoy Hotel, is returning there shortly.

This week's arrivals at the Savoy Hotel include Lord and Lady Craven, the Duke of Montremart, Marquis d'Audriffet Pasquier, Prince de Tonnay Charente, Paris ; Mr. Adolph Phillip, Baronne Reinlein, Count Preysing, Count Hervé d'Hunolstein, Baron Griessenbeck, Germany ; M. and Mme Benachi, Mr. and Mrs. James Speyer, New York, Mr. and Mrs. A. M. Huntingdon.
Among those landing at Port Said for Cairo by the P. & 0. S.S. "Oceana" yesterday after noon were Lady Nesta Fitzgerald, Sir Allen Lewis and Miss Lewis, and the Hon. Mrs. F. Barry.
Mr. and Mrs. Brodley Martin and the Earl and Countess of Craven ate leaving on a dababieh for Upper Egypt. They will rettien to the Savoy at the end of February.

Arabi Pasha and his former companions in exile in Ceylon will be sorry to hear that their former guardian, Sir George Campbell, has just succumbed to pneumonia. He had charge of Arabi Pasha and the other Egyptian prisoners while in Ceylon from 1882 till 1891. The Inspector-Generalship of Ceylon Prisons was added to his police duties from 1884 until his retirement from the colony in 1891.

div.head: CHRQNIQÜE_JUD ICI AIRE
div.p: COUR D'APPEL MIXTE
Un cas d'infection*

Une nourrice italienne ayant été infectée d'une maladie grave par l'enfant qui lui avait été confiée par un négociant européen de Zagazig, attaqua celui-ci par devant le tribunal mixte' de Mansourah. Elle réclamait une forte some de dommages-intérêts,

Après enquête et expertise ordonnée parlui, le tribunal de Mansourah condamna le négociant à payer à la demanderesse 1° une somme de quatre cents livres à titre de réparation du préjudice qu elle a souffert et souffrira personnellement; 2 une autre somme de cent livres pour réparations des frais et honoraires qu'elle a. dû et devra débourser pour le soin de sa santé et la défense de ses droits, avec les intérêts à cinq pour cent du jour de la demande en justice 6 décembre 1900; il condamna enfin le défendeur aux dépens, y compris les frais de I'instance en référé vidée par l'ordonnance etdes expertises auxquelles il avait été procédé IL y eut appel de ce jugement, suivi d'un ar rêt interlocutoire le 13 Janvier 1904, ordonnant une expertise médicale.

La Cour, par son arrêt de ce matin, déclare mai fondé l'appel du jugement. Les experts nommés par la Cour confirment pleinement les constatations résultant .des mesures d'instruction ordonnées par les premièrs juges et sur lesquelles ils ont fondé leur décision. Quant à l'appel incident, la Cour, tout en reconnaissant qu'il s'agitd'un fait dommageable imputable au négociant et dont il est dû réparation, dit que ce fait ne peut cependant être retenu comme lo résultat d'une intention réfléchie et perverse ; que la réparation accordée par le tribunal paraît donc proportionnée au préjudice souffert et par conséquent suffisante.
Affaire du Canal de SUEZ

Une affaire concernant les parts de fondateurs du Canal de Suez, analogue à celles déjà plaidées, est venue ce matin devant la Cour. L'appelante, la dame Amina Hanem Toussoun, ne s'étant pas fait représenter, l'avocat de la Cie., Me Vermond, a requis un arrêt par défaut, qui sera rendu à huitaine.
La dame fera probablement opposition à cet arrêt

Un Incident Me Tramoni, l'avocat suspendu, s'est présenté ce matin à la barre à titre d'intervenant, personnellement intéressé dans deux appels, 'Les avocats des deux parties adverses ayant voulu protester contre cette intervention, Me Tramoui a été invité par le Président, M. Meriondo, à exposer les motifs de son intervention.

•Après une discussion mouvementée, le presidentarenvoyé le prononcé de son arrêt à quinzaine sur la recevabilité de l'intervention. Si celle-ci est admise, une date ultérieure sera fixée pour les plaidoieries.
M. de Korizmics, qui présidait l'audience, avait été récusé par Me Tramoni et c'est pour cette raison que M. Moriondo avait dû prendre sa place.
Délégation Municipale
(Communication officielle)

La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 17 janvier 1905 à 4 h. p.m, sous la présidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli. Présents : MM. P. Fenderl, Mansour Bey Youssef, Soliman Bey Abani, E. Stross, Dr. G. Valensin, membres, W. P. Chataway, adminis-. trateur, I. Sedky, secrétaire.
La Délégation s'occupe de diverses questions de détail concernant les quais et collecteurs et leur donne la suite voulue.
Elle étudie la question de construction d'une conduite d'eau filtrée à Ramleh et charge M. FenderL et M. Chataway de se mettre en rapport avec le directeur de la Cie des Eaux à ce sujet.
La Délégation émet un avis favorable à divers excédents et emprises qu'elle soumettra à la Commission Municipale.
Elle décide d'entourer d'une grille le terrain contournant la Colonne Pompée.
* La Délégation décide de mettre en adjudication les travaux suivants 1° l'empierrement en caillasse de la rue de Siouf jusqu'à la rue El ekbal.
2° l'empierrement en caillasse de la route d'Aboukir, du bazar Bacos au passage à niveau de la station Gabrial.
3° la mise en état de la route d'Asnières à l'Ibrahimieh.
4° l'empierrement de la route du Palais de Ras-el-Tin à l'hôpital militaire anglais. La Délégation renvoie aux services pour rapport les offres relatives à la fourniture de bersim'.

Elle prend note d'une lettre ministérielle du 16 janvier 1905 informant que l'inspection générale des pharmacies pour la ville d'Alexandrie et ses faubourgs sera effectuée par les services de la Municipalité.
La séance est levée à 8h. p.m.
Le Prince Biza

Nous venons de recevoir le volume contenant la vie et les poésies du prince Riza, ambassade'ur de Perse à Constantinople. Ce prince, littérateur et poète en même temps que diplomatique, est une figure à part dans le inonde diplomatique. Un de ses principaux titres de gloire est sans contredit la part importante qu'il a prise à la Conférence de La Haye. Apôtre de la paix universelle, il répand partout sa doctrine humanitaire.
S. A. le Prince Riza est actuellement en Egypte, Après un court séjour à Ramleh, ilyient de partir pour la Caire,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURBE
div.p: (Aujourd' à midi et demie)

Aujourd'hui le marché en général est plutôt calme. Il faut excepter, cependant, les Banques Nationale et Agricole qui ont donné Heu à beaucoup de transactions et haussé, la première de 24 9/16 à 24 15/16 et la seconde de 10 1/8 à 10 3/8. La demande sur ces deux valeurs est très active

La Delta Land réactionne à 3 7/8 acheteurs, la Daïra Sanieh à 22 3/8 vendeurs, la Crown Brewery à 215, les Markets à 23/3 acheteurs, la Banque d'Athènes à 125, la Nungovich à 9 15/16 et l'Anglo American Nile à 5 1/8.
La Ramleh Railway monte, au contraire, de 8 1/4 à 8 5/16. r
Les Cotton Mills sont fermes à 7/6 acheteurs.

div.p: Alexandria and Ramleh Rly. Co, Ltd.
AVIB.

Les porteurs des obligations hypothecaires de l'Alexandria and R mleh Railway Co Ltd., émission de 1887 sont invités à présenter aux bureaux de h Compagnie au plus tard le 81 Janvier courant pour échanger leurs obligations contre de nouvelles obligations ordinaires de la Compagnie, aux mêmes conditions d'intérêt et d'amortissement et garanties d'une manière générale par l'avoir de la Compagnie, ou bien, s'ils le préfèrent, pour recevoir le remboursement de leurs obligations hypothécaires dont le Conseil d'Administration a décidé le retrait par suite de l'aliénation d'une partie des immeubles compris dans l'hypothèque. Les intérêts cessent de courir aprè la date sue-mentionnee du 81 Janvier courant pur toutes obligations qui ne seront pas présentées à l'échange ou eu remboursement avant cette date.
Alexandrie, le 18 Janvier 1905.
Par ordre du Conseil d'Administration,
Le Directeur,
(Signé) J.G. Jacot

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
div.p: PROGRESS AT SHEIKH BARGHOUT.
SIR W. GARSTIN'S INSPECTION.
Suakin, January 10.

Sir William Garstin, G.C.M.G., Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works, accompanied by Miralai Macauley Bey, R.E., Director of Sudan Railways, and Bimbashi Sowerby, R.E., Chief Engineer of Ways and Works, Suakin-Atbara Railways, left for Railhead on the 4th inst. in a special train composed of four saloon carriages on inspection duty, returning to Suakin at. noon on the 7th inst. The same afternoon, Sir Wm. Gars tin,accompanied by Macau ley Bey, inspected the piers and the works at Graham's Point. His Excellency expressed his entire satisfaction with what he saw and with the great progress made in such, a short space of time, and under many difficulties.

On the 8th inst. Sir William Garstin, accompanied by Macauley Bey and Drury Bey, Controller of Sudan Ports, left on H.H. Ports and Lighthouses steamer "Aida,"which was followed by the Sudan Port steam tug "Hawk," for Sheikh Barghout harbour. After the party had landed and inspected this new port, Sir Wm. Garstin went on to Suez by the "Aida," and Macauley Bey and Drury Bey returned. to Suakin by the "Hawk."
The British steamer "Sharistan" arrived there from England with a large consignment of railway material and stores for the Sudan Government Railway on the 4th inst.
H.M.S. "Sealark" (Commander Somerville) arrived here from Sheikh Barghout on the 4th inst. and left again lor surveying purposes on the 7th inst.

One officer and 35 N.C.O. s and men belonging to the Works Department arrived here on the 7th inst. from Khartoum via Berber, and are leaving for Sheikh Barghout. They form the pioneer party and will start the public works there. They will soon be followed by about 1,000 more men from the same department coming via Suez. The total number of men to be sent to Sheikh Barghout in connection with the public works there will amount to about 3,000.

The anniversary of the accession to the Throne of H. H. the Khedive was observed as a general holiday, all Government offices and works being closed for the occasion. At midday a salute of 21 guns was fired from the Customs' Quay, and the town was anfete by day as well as by night.

The Khedivial mail steamer "Missir'' arrived here a few days ago from Suez with a consignment of timber, etc., for the temporary wooden bridges te erected for the Suakin-Atbara Railway. The returns to Suez to-day.
THE PICNIC GIRL.
WHAT SHE HAS TO PUT UP WITH.

The Picnic Girl goes out for pleasure; but she has much to put up with. She must mix the salad, and keep the earwigs out of it, aud she mustn't scream when a spider walks over her hand. Sometimes a burst of rain spoils her pretty frock : but she must still look cheerful and try to pretend that she likes it. And,these showers do more than spoil frocks, as a Liverpool lady told her friend the other day. "I was a girl at a picnic, and got drenched to the skin," she said. "And I have blamed that picnic ever since for the way. I have suffered with rheumatism. "Only those who have ever suffered from that dreadful malady can have any idea of the awful pain I had at times to bear. For week after week I have been bed-ridden. Besides which I had that miserable languor which is so horribly depressing. At night I have often been in too great pain to sleep.

"There was hardly a part of my body which was not at one time or another affected with the rheumatism," continued the speaker (Mrs. Moorcroft, of 88, Leven-street, Kirkdale, Liverpool). "My appetite almost completely left me, and when I did get the length of walking even a few yards I soon became tired out, both with the pain and difficulty experienced in breathing. I despaired, after I had suffered in the way I have described for many years, of ever being like other people again. Nothing did me any good until I tried Dr. Williams' pink pills, Three boxes effected an improvement, and as I persevered with them a little time I soon felt quite well again, and have been so now for a long time. My appetite has returned ; I am able to sleep ; l have no pain, and I find pleasure in working."

Mrs. Moorcroft's case is like many others. She needed new blood to cure her rheumatism, and Dr. Williams pink pills cured her by making new blood, just as they have cured so many cases of anaemia, bile, consumption, decline, fits, St. Vitus' dance, hysteria, and the many troubles which women silently endure. It is important to insist on having genuine pills, with Dr. Williams name, as some shopkeepers push useless substitutes.
Sold in Egypt by all chemists at P.T. 13 per box or P.T. 70 per 6 boxes. Can be bought at the general dépôt : Max Fischer, Cairo, Hotel du Nil St. (1st floor), and Alexandria, Rue Stamboul, No. 8,

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: HELOUAN SECOND WINTER MEETING.
The following is the programme of the races to be held at Helouan | on Saturday, 4th February, at 2.30 p.m., under the rules and with the co-operation of the stewards of the Khedivial Sporting Club:—
FIRST RACE, 2.30 p.m.
Maiden Pony Race.—Value P.T. 2500, 2nd horse to receive P.T. 300, and 3rd horse P.T. 200 out of the stakes. For Arab ponies, weight for age and inches. Distance mile. Entrance P.T. 200.
SECOND RACE, 3 p.m.

The United Service Handicap. —Value P.T. 2,000, 2nd horse to receive P.T. 300, and 3rd horse P.T. 200 out of the stakes. For Arabs the property of Officers of the Army of Occupation ; British and Egyptian Officers of the Egyptian Army and British Civilians of the Egyptian Government. Distance 7 furlongs. Entrance P.T. 100.
THIRD RACE, 3.30 p.m.
Maiden Galloway.—Value P.T. 2,500, 2nd horse to receive P.T. 300 and 3rd P.T. 200, out of the stakes. For Arabs, weight for age and inches. Distance about 1 mile. Entrance
FOURTH RACE, 4 p.m.

Helouan Derby.—Value P.T. 15,000,2ndhorse to receive P.T. 2,000, and 3rd horse P.T. 1,000 out of the stakes. For Maiden (at nomination) Arabs, weight for age with! penalties, reduced 7lbs. Distance about 1 mile 1 furlong. Entry by subscription and nomination as follows : Subscription on 1st . June, 1904, P.T. 200, with P.T. 300 on nomination on 1st October, 1904, and with a further charge of P.T. 250 if left in after the 1st of January, 1905.
This race having been published before the revision of the Khedivial Sporting Club rules, will be run under the old scale of weights.
FIFTH RACE, 4.30 p.m.

Tewfik Handicap.— Value P.T. 6,500, 2ud horse to receive P.T. 1,000, and 3rd horse P.T. 500 out of the stakes. For Arab ponies. Top weight not to exceed list. Distance 1 mile 1 furlong. Entrance on the 1st October, 1904 P.T. 300 and on the 28th January, 1905, when the race closes, P.T. 500.
SIXTH RACE, 5. p.m.

Trial Plate.— Value P.T. 2,500, 2nd horse to receive P.T. 300, and 3rd horse P.T. 200 out of the stakes. For Arab horses, galloways and ponies that have never won a race of any description (Gymkhanas excepted). Weight for age, galloways allowed 4 lbs. and ponies 7 lbs. Distance 3/4 mile. Entrance P.T. 200.
SEVENTH RACE, 5.30 p.m. Bedouin Stakes.—Value P.T. 2,500, 2nd horse to receive P.T. 300, and 3rd horse P.T.

200 out of the stakes. For Arabs that have never won a race of any description. Open to all members and non-members who do not keep racing horses. Catch weights over l0st. 7lbs. for horses, lOst for galloways and 9st. 7lbs. for ponies. Distance : 1 mile 1 furlong. Entrance P.T. 125. Unless 15 horses are en? tered half the above stakes will be given. Entrance fee to be paid at the time of entry, Measuring day for this race Saturday, 4th February, at 10 a.m. at H:S.C. paddock, Helouan.
The entries will close at 6 p.m. on Saturday the 28th January, 1905, to the Clerk of the Course, Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan.
Measuring-day will be Friday, 20th January, 1905, at 3 p.m. at Ghezireh.

All horses and ponies not already registered to be aged ; and. those whose measurement at 5 years old and upwards are not recorded in K. S. C. or A. S. C. registers to be measured. There will be no lotteries.
The order of running will be the same as that in which the races are on this programme.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
